fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-22469].
  {panel}

When creating a project with the Plugin SDK (version 3.2) one gets a pom with those dependencies:
{code:xml}
    <dependencies>
        <dependency>
            <groupId>com.atlassian.jira</groupId>
            <artifactId>atlassian-jira</artifactId>
            <version>${jira.version}</version>
            <scope>provided</scope>
        </dependency>        
        <dependency>
            <groupId>junit</groupId>
            <artifactId>junit</artifactId>
            <version>4.6</version>
            <scope>test</scope>
        </dependency>
        <dependency>
            <groupId>com.atlassian.jira</groupId>
            <artifactId>jira-func-tests</artifactId>
            <version>${jira.version}</version>
            <scope>test</scope>
        </dependency>
    </dependencies>
{code}

The {{jira.version}} is set to 4.1.2 in this case.

What happens is that when someone uses the servlet API in their, as it is sometimes required by JIRA's own API usage, it doesn't compile. Looking at the dependency tree for the servlet-api make it obvious:

First running:
{noformat}
mvn dependency:tree -Dincludes=*:servlet-api:*:*

[INFO] [dependency:tree]
[INFO] com.atlassian.plugins.tutorial:jira-report-plugin:atlassian-plugin:1.0-SNAPSHOT
[INFO] \- com.atlassian.jira:jira-func-tests:jar:4.1.2:test
[INFO]    \- javax.servlet:servlet-api:jar:2.3:test

{noformat}

It shows that the servlet-api's scope is {{test}}, when one expects it to be {{provided}}. 

{noformat}
mvn dependency:tree -Dincludes=*:servlet-api:*:* -Dverbose

[INFO] [dependency:tree]
[INFO] com.atlassian.plugins.tutorial:jira-report-plugin:atlassian-plugin:1.0-SNAPSHOT
[INFO] +- com.atlassian.jira:atlassian-jira:jar:4.1.2:provided
[INFO] |  +- com.atlassian.ofbiz:atlassian-ofbiz:jar:2.7.3:provided
[INFO] |  |  \- (javax.servlet:servlet-api:jar:2.3:provided - omitted for duplicate)
[INFO] |  +- com.atlassian.plugins:atlassian-plugins-webresource:jar:2.4.4:provided
[INFO] |  |  \- (javax.servlet:servlet-api:jar:2.3:provided - omitted for duplicate)
[INFO] |  +- com.atlassian.security.auth.trustedapps:atlassian-trusted-apps-core:jar:2.1:provided
[INFO] |  |  \- (javax.servlet:servlet-api:jar:2.3:provided - omitted for duplicate)
[INFO] |  +- com.atlassian.gzipfilter:atlassian-gzipfilter:jar:1.9:provided
[INFO] |  |  \- (javax.servlet:servlet-api:jar:2.3:provided - omitted for duplicate)
[INFO] |  +- org.apache.velocity:velocity-tools:jar:1.3:provided
[INFO] |  |  \- (javax.servlet:servlet-api:jar:2.3:provided - omitted for duplicate)
[INFO] |  \- commons-jelly:commons-jelly:jar:1.0:provided
[INFO] |     \- (javax.servlet:servlet-api:jar:2.3:provided - omitted for duplicate)
[INFO] \- com.atlassian.jira:jira-func-tests:jar:4.1.2:test
[INFO]    +- net.sourceforge.jwebunit:jwebunit:jar:1.2-atlassian-1:test
[INFO]    |  \- (javax.servlet:servlet-api:jar:2.3:test - omitted for duplicate)
[INFO]    +- com.meteware.httpunit:httpunit:jar:1.5.4-atlassian-8:test
[INFO]    |  \- (javax.servlet:servlet-api:jar:2.3:test - omitted for duplicate)
[INFO]    \- javax.servlet:servlet-api:jar:2.3:test
{noformat}

This shows that the servler-api is NOT a direct dependency of {{atlassian-jira}} when I believe it should be. This would solve the compilation problem. This is a problem a few plugin developers have had and are puzzled by most of the time.
fields.summary: Explicitly declare the servlet API as a dependency for 'atlassian-jira'

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-22428].
  {panel}

Hello ;

I am currently developing a new Jira plugin. As a result, I have to create new pages in the administration menu. These pages are build on the same metamodel as the "Add a new project" page. 

As a matter of fact, I developed them using some features provided by JSP, based on the same way as the new project page. 

The thing is : 
I cannot use any internationalisation language file for displaying some text information on my JSP. For instance, the addproject.jsp uses some keys (common.words.name) to display elements. The values of these keys are located in some .properties language files (like JiraWebActionSupport.properties). In the JSP I am developing, I have to create my own keys, because they are specific to my plugin. 

Actually, I have already my own .properties file (located in my plugin dir : myPlugin/src/main/resources/com/.../jira/plugins/myPlugin.properties). This file works perfectly for the atlassian-plugin.xml file (My keys appear properly in the admin panel menu). If I call the JSP directly, it works, my .properties file is properly loaded too. But this is not a good way to use JSP in Jira. This is not true if I call my .jspa class, my page will appear, but it will not load my .properties file : the page will display my keys instead (myplugin.words.name for instance)

Is it possible to find a way to give Jira an extra feature to include a new .properties file? I don't want to modify Jira files directly, because they are about to be overwritten at each new upgrade of Jira. 

I want to develop these pages using JSP because : 
- I need to use the component to select users using JQL features (which is implemented by the userselect.jsp template)
- Java Server Pages are far easier to use than the Velocity views

I submitted this as a new feature, because I believe that the use of JSP will affect more and more Jira developers ; Anyway, if I made something wrong in my development, if my request is already implemented, please could you give me a trick on how to use it?

Yours sincerely, 
Nicolas L
fields.summary: Internationalisation using JSP servlets : ability to link another .properties file
Searching part of the URL does not return result

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-22417].
  {panel}

Hi, some users complain that when someone adds an attachment to an issue while adding a comment at the same time (cf. screenshot), event "Issue Commented" is not raised. 
Same occurs if the user sends an email to add a comment to the issue and the email has an image in the signature (or any attachment).

Consequently, they do not receive any notification email, whereas the comment does appear actually in the list of comments.

Would it be possible to raise event "Issue Commented" as soon as an attachment is added along with a comment?

Thanks.


+*Workaround:*+
The event that is fired in this scenario is 'Issue Updated'.  Notifications can be configured for the event Issue Updated type within Notification Scheme.
fields.summary: Adding an Attachment AND Commenting OR send an email with an attachment Should Raise Event "Issue Commented"

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-22403].
  {panel}

I want to be able to create a custom field that is used for 2 different issue types -- say Bug & Improvement.  For Bug issues, I want the options to be A,B,C,D.  For Improvement, I want the options to be A,B,D,E,F.

JIRA only allows me to define 1 global context -- not having to select specific projects -- for the custom field.  So if I set up a context for Bug issues w/ options A/B/C/D regardless of project, if I want to then define the context for Improvement issues with its separate options, I'm forced to explicitly select one or more projects to apply this to -- even though I want it to apply to Improvement issues in all projects.

This is a serious maintenance problem.  As soon as I add more projects, I now have to remember to go back to my custom field and add those projects to the Improvement issue context.  That's ridiculous.

Is there a workaround for this?

If you made Project Categories a 1st class, usable object in JIRA, at the very least you could allow us to define a separate context by Project category which would then automatically apply to all future Projects in that Category without having to explicitly add each & every Project into the Custom Field context as new ones are created.
fields.summary: Ability to define multiple global contexts for custom fields

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-22391].
  {panel}

Hi,

While tuning out Jira instance (400 000 issues, 3000 users, 800 concurrent sessions) we have observed that LuceneUtils.stringToDate() takes 20-30% of the total CPU time calling org.apache.lucene.document.DateTools.stringToDate(s) that uses "new SimpleDateFormat().parse()"

I'd like to submit a possible optimisation of this function (to be called from LuceneUtils.stringToDate()) that behaves as DateTools.stringToDate() but runs some 7000% faster. For example, 200000 conversions take 78.0 millis instead of 5625.0 before.

Cheers, 
Vitaliy Shevchuk
fields.summary: string2Date optimisation possibility

The gadget is hardcoded to filter issue using 'In Progress' status whereby if the statuses are in other language the filter will not be able to find it.

To replicate the problem:
# Install JIRA using other language (eg:French)
# Translate the statuses to French (eg: "In Progress" to "En Cours") 
# Add the Issues In Progress gadget into the dashboard
# Create new issue and transition it to "En Cours" status
# refresh the "Issues In Progress" gadget and the result will be empty.
# click on the link to the Issue Filter in the gadget, the filter is hard coded as shown below:
!InProgress.png!

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-22351].
  {panel}

h2. Issue Description

Deleting a version from the project version which has issue still associated with them does not remove the entries from {{nodeassociation}} table. This causes the JQL query {{fixVersion is EMPTY}} not able to return those issues despite there is no Version associated.

h2. Steps to replicate

# Create a project version
# Associate to an issue's fixVersion
# Delete the project version and select remove version
# Verify the fixVersion is now shown as none
# Run JQL query for {{fixVersion is EMPTY}}
# Notice that the issue on step 2 does not list as result

h2. Expected Result
Returning the issue since the version is no longer valid

h2. Workaround
Delete the entries from the {{nodeassociation}} table manually for those issues that have no reference to the {{projectversion}} table:
{panel:borderStyle=solid| borderColor=#6A8EB3|bgColor=#F8F8F8}
(!) *Important*: Always take a *full backup* from your database before doing any direct changes on database level - Please refer to the [Backing Up Data|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Backing+Up+Data] for more details.
{panel}
# Verify how many affected entry using:
{code:sql|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#6A8EB3|bgColor=#F8F8F8}
select (p.pkey || '-' || i.issuenum) as issuekey, n.sink_node_entity, n.sink_node_id 
from jiraissue i, project p, nodeassociation n 
where i.id = n.source_node_id
and i.project = p.id
and source_node_entity = 'Issue'
and sink_node_entity = 'Version' 
and sink_node_id not in (select id from projectversion);
{code}
(i) The above query does not work prior to JIRA 6.1
# Stop JIRA.
# Deleting the entries from the database:
{code:sql|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#6A8EB3|bgColor=#F8F8F8}
delete from nodeassociation where source_node_entity = 'Issue' and sink_node_entity = 'Version' and sink_node_id not in (select id from projectversion);
{code}
# Start JIRA.
# [Re-index JIRA|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jira/search-indexing-185729671.html].

For JIRA Cloud customers, please raise an issue at [support|https://support.atlassian.com/customer/createIssue] and select JIRA Cloud project for assistance. 

Previous Description is located below:
{noformat}
I've worked around the problem described below by doing:

DELETE a.* FROM nodeassociation a
LEFT JOIN projectversion v ON a.SINK_NODE_ID = v.ID
WHERE a.ASSOCIATION_TYPE = 'IssueFixVersion'
AND v.ID IS NULL;

------ Forwarded Message
From: Justin de Vesine
Date: Thu, 23 Sep 2010 14:16:37 -0500
To: Matt McClure
Subject: Re: JIRA fixVersion appears as None, but doesn't match "fixVersion is EMPTY" query

This SQL query demonstrates the two healthy and one unhealthy case: MMF-3602, which has a fixversion; MMF-82, which doesn't have a fix version (and shows up in a JQL query like "fixVersion IS EMPTY and key = MMF-82"); MMF-92 (which has a fixversion which got deleted).

SELECT `jiraissue`.`pkey` AS `issue`, `nodeassociation`.`SOURCE_NODE_ID` AS `version_id`, `projectversion`.`vname` AS `version_name` FROM `jiraissue` LEFT JOIN `nodeassociation` ON `nodeassociation`.`SOURCE_NODE_ENTITY` = "Issue" AND `nodeassociation`.`SOURCE_NODE_ID` = `jiraissue`.`ID` AND `nodeassociation`.`SINK_NODE_ENTITY` = "Version" LEFT JOIN `projectversion` ON `projectversion`.`ID` = `nodeassociation`.`SINK_NODE_ID` WHERE `jiraissue`.`pkey` IN ('MMF-92', 'MMF-82', "MMF-3602") 

version_id and version_name both set or both null is good; only version_id set indicates the ticket has no valid fixversion but fixversion is not empty.

It appears that we have 990 such invalid fixversions set on various tickets:

SELECT `jiraissue`.`pkey` AS `issue`, `nodeassociation`.`SOURCE_NODE_ID` AS `version_id`, `projectversion`.`vname` AS `version_name` FROM `jiraissue` LEFT JOIN `nodeassociation` ON `nodeassociation`.`SOURCE_NODE_ENTITY` = "Issue" AND `nodeassociation`.`SOURCE_NODE_ID` = `jiraissue`.`ID` AND `nodeassociation`.`SINK_NODE_ENTITY` = "Version" LEFT JOIN `projectversion` ON `projectversion`.`ID` = `nodeassociation`.`SINK_NODE_ID` WHERE `nodeassociation`.`SINK_NODE_ID` IS NOT NULL AND `projectversion`.`vname` IS NULL

and cleaning them up (once you have satisfied your investigations) appears to be simple (DELETE FROM nodeassociation WHERE {stuff}).

It does not appear that the integrity tools built into JIRA or GreenHopper detect this issue.

-Justin

On Sep 23, 2010, at 10:41 AM, Matt McClure wrote:

This query finds the issue:

https://jira/secure/IssueNavigator.jspa?reset=true&jqlQuery=key+%3D+MMF-92+AND+(fixVersion+not+in+releasedVersions()+OR+fixVersion+is+EMPTY+OR+fixVersion+in+unreleasedVersions())+AND+issuetype+in+(%22Theme:+Tier+1%22,+%22Theme:+Tier+2%22)+AND+NOT+status+in+(Closed,+Resolved)+ORDER+BY+Rank+ASC,+key+ASC

This query does not:

https://jira/secure/IssueNavigator.jspa?reset=true&jqlQuery=key+%3D+MMF-92+AND+(fixVersion+is+EMPTY+OR+fixVersion+in+unreleasedVersions())+AND+issuetype+in+(%22Theme:+Tier+1%22,+%22Theme:+Tier+2%22)+AND+NOT+status+in+(Closed,+Resolved)+ORDER+BY+Rank+ASC,+key+ASC

Hypothesis 1: The issue has a fixVersion that no longer exists.

Hypothesis 2: There is a bug in JIRA or Greenhopper that corrupts fixVersion data on some issues.

Another observation: The query below matches 61 issues:

https://jira/secure/IssueNavigator.jspa?reset=true&jqlQuery=fixVersion+not+in+releasedVersions()+and+fixVersion+not+in+unreleasedVersions()+and+fixVersion+is+not+EMPTY
{noformat}
fields.summary: Deleting a version that has associated issues makes those issues fail to match fixVersion is EMPTY JQL queries

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-22315].
  {panel}

See the attached screenshot of the problem. Essentially the login bar does not fill up 100% of the screen after adding the columns. It looks like the Login bar is fitted for 100% of the origional screen size. So if you make the browser box smaller the problem will appear. On a large screen will not appear because the bar is configured to fill 100% of that screen already. The exact steps as follows:

1. Click the "view" button to search issues in the issue navigator screen.

2. Select the "configure columns", and then click it to enter issue 
configure columns screen.

3. Select the new columns(for example: Description, Project, and so on), 
and then click the "add" button to add them.

4. Click the "issue" icon on menu bar to return to the issue navigator 
screen.

5. Move the scrollbar from left to right, and then you will see this 
problem in the top right corner of screen.

By the way, we have not use the proxy server to access the website.

Attached please find the XML backup for this problem.
fields.summary: Login Header Not Fitting 100% of the Screen

fields.description:
I have an embedded javascript file in header-deprecated.jsp. Whenever I update the JS file, I see the updated javascript on Issue Creation page  by refreshing the page prior to JIRA 4.x. After upgrading to JIRA 4.x, I could not see any updated javascript, yet see the old javascript. 

In JIRA 4.x, it looks like the jsp file doesn't get compiled correctly with JDK1.6.0_20. While the javascript gets updated only after reboot with JDK1.6.0_18, the javascript never gets updated even after reboot with JDK1.6.0_20

Is there a way the updated javascript to be effective without rebooting jira instance with JDK1.6.0_20?

BTW, I have a prototype running on production that uses the embedded javascript.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-22256].
  {panel}

*Summary*
{{IssueNavigator}} calls every instance of a JQL function's getValues() three times 
# to validate the query
# to get the query's issues
# to see if the query fits in the simple filter form [getQueryContext()]
If the JQL function has to inspect a lot of data or returns a lot data, this leads to severe performance issues unexpectedly multiply.

*Detailed Explanation*
As some Atlassians know, we wedged Mike Cannon-Brookes prototype of advanced search into our Jira 3.13 and made enhancements to search change history and all the comment fields.
I've been working to adapt what we did to work in Jira 4.

In Jira 3, this required a heavy-handed modification of the {{LuceneQueryCreator}} so that a Lucene Filter on the comment index was properly or'ed or and'ed or not'ed against the issue index. It was messy but it worked. The performance was OK as long as the user didn't have too many queries against the comment index as sub-queries. 

For Jira 4, I figured that using a JQL function to search on the comment index and then return JiraDataType.ISSUE was the cleaner way to do what we had done by hacking {{LuceneQueryCreator}} in Jira 3. The JQL function searches the comment index and returns a list of issue id's. The rest would be handled by in Jira 4's great new re-worked search system and I could encapsulate everything in a plugin.  

What I did works, but it has horrible performance.  
{{IssueNavigator}} calls every instance of the function's getValues() three times 
# to validate the query
# to get the query's issues
# to see if the query fits in the simple filter form [getQueryContext()]

This means that my comment JQL function has to search the comment index 3 times, loop 3 times through each hit on the comment index and convert it to an issue id, and then the system re-queries the issue index using those issue ids in a new search 3 times. 
In our Jira 3 implementation the comment index was searched once, converted to a Lucene Filter and then filtered once against the issue index using Lucene.  Here are averages of a couple comparisons that I did on the same machine running both Jira 3 and Jira 4
||issues||Jira 3||Jira 4||
|500|5 seconds|5 seconds|
|30000|23 seconds|190 seconds|
|100000|53 seconds|10 minutes|

(I also noticed that if an issue in the results is for some reason invalid -- for example if it fell victim to [Bulk Edit woes|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-18453] -- then after the user has waited minutes to get their slow running results, instead of getting all their issues with a warning note about the invalid issues, they get zero results and an error message which doesn't indicate what went wrong.  See [invalid-issue.png|http://jira.atlassian.com/secure/attachment/40814/invalid-issue.png].  I've filed a separate bug on this, JRA-22277.)

I believe *JQL needs several an improvements*
# getValues() should only be called once not 3 times per function. Perhaps wrap the call to the function in an object that holds onto the values while it gets passed from validation to query to context anaylysis. Another idea, add an isTooComplexForSimpleSearch() method to the JqlFunction interface that would negate the need to run the query for most functions
# The returning of issue id's from JqlFunction.getValues() is almost always going to lead to a poor-performance situation because whatever the function does to discover issue ids is going to be expensive. Perhaps it should be deprecated.  *Update* I also have concern for the User functions. For example, I wrote another one that returns all the users that are no longer active so that project leads can re-assign issues that are assigned to employees who no longer work at our company. This function has to loop through all the users and find which ones no longer belong to any groups. The JQL framework also runs this function three times per function call.
# -Perhaps the better alternative would be to have a JiraDataType.FILTER so that getValues would return a Lucene Filter.- _after analyzing the issue further myself, I realize that this isn't a valid suggestion_

*Update, September 15*
After studying this for a couple days, I was able to speed up our system with 4 changes:
# To stop it from looping through thousands of issues and constructing an issue for each before the query executes, I commented out the validation code in {{IssueIdValidator}}
# I modified {{IssueIdQueryFactory}} to construct an IssueIdFilter wrapped by a ConstantScoreQuery rather than a BooleanQuery with a sub-query for each issue id. This avoids the Too Many Clauses Error if the JQL function hits more than 32000 issues. This is similar to the solution that I posed in JRA-22453. See code below.
# I modified {{MultiClauseDecoratorContextFactory}} so that it only loops through the first 100 results during getQueryContext().
# To work around but not solve the problem of {{IssueNavigator}} calling each instance of a JQL function 3 times, I put a cache in my JQL issue-type functions that holds onto each instance's results for a few seconds. This consumes unnecessary memory but it's the best that I can think of short of re-writing the entire JQL call framework to hold onto the results and then pass them through validate(), executeQuery(), and getQueryContext() rather than having validate(), executeQuery(), and getQueryContext() each separately calling jqlIssueFunction.getValues().
# To avoid unneccessarily calling isCurrentQueryTooComplex(), I hacked our {{IssueNavigator.isAdvanced()}} to have a regular expression that recognizes if there's a JQL string that matches one of our nasty custom JQL issue-type functions.

With these improvements, our Jira 4 now runs faster than Jira 3!  Yay!  
New results
||issues||Jira 3||Jira 4||
|500|5 seconds|4 seconds|
|30000|23 seconds|8 seconds|
|100000|53 seconds|23 seconds|

(Digression -- another improvement request that I contemplate -- get rid of the issue index and index everything, including change history, inside the comment index)

{code:java|title=IssueIdQueryFactory.java}
    private Query createPositiveEqualsQuery(final List<QueryLiteral> rawValues)
    {
        if (rawValues.size() == 1)
        {
            return createQuery(rawValues.get(0));
        }
        else
        {
            return new ConstantScoreQuery(new IssueIdFilter(rawValues));
        }
    }
{code}

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-22195].
  {panel}

In the Solaris environment, the 32bit version of the JRE/JDK is the baseline and the 64bit is either a sparcv9 on a SPARC chip or an amd64 on an x86 chip (i.e. intel or amd).

All the scripts that would called the JVM are using
 $JAVA_HOME/bin/java (i.e. the 32bit)  instead of the $JAVA_HOME/bin/amd64/java (i.e. the 64bit). 

Since the application (i.e. Jira) and/or the application server that it sits on (i.e. Tomcat) can not determine the instruction set (i.e. 64 vs 32), then setting the JAVA_HOME to the JDK home is  not enough.
fields.summary: setting the JAVA_HOME to the JDK home is not enough on Solaris 10 x86/64bit

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-22177].
  {panel}

When building project key patterns, custom patterns should be wrapped in parentheses.

See class DefaultKeyMatcher constructor.

See support issue https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-63357

In essence, subtle pattern match problems can arise, if the JIRA administrator provides a pattern which has alternates.

Assume for the moment that the administrator provides this simple key pattern: 

   ALPHA|BETA

Then, the project key regular pattern will be constructed as

   /^ALPHA|BETA$/

Which will match any of the following

   ALPHA
   ALPHA-DOG
   BETA
   5BETA
   %^&^&**()BETA

Does this make sense?

The proper pattern should be:

   /^(ALPHA|BETA)$/

Since I'm unfamiliar with the Perl5Util classes, I can only ask why the need to enclose the entire pattern in stroke characters.  From my knowledge of Perl, the stroke characters are part of the syntax used to indicate that there is a pattern, and they are not maintained as part of the pattern.
fields.summary: Add Guarding Parentheses in DefaultKeyMatcher class

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-22163].
  {panel}

Today Atlassian recommends character set encoding UTF8 for Oracle database. 
But Oracle recommends that if the environment (clients and servers) consists entirely of Oracle 9i or higher, use AL32UTF8 as NLS_CHARACTERSET, otherwise use UTF8.
As far as I know, the AL32UTF8 is equivalent to the standard UTF-8. The difference is that AL32UTF8 is more appropriate for XML data.
I would be great if someone could test compatibility between JIRA and this character set encoding, and if it's not, make it compatible.

Please let me know if you need further explanation.

Regards,
____________________
Felipe Kraemer
Atlassian Support
fields.summary: AL32UTF8 Character Encoding Compatibility

When I went to authorise a JAC gadget on Extranet, I was redirected to the following URL:

Thanks for trying out the new REST api!

With 4.2, we shipped an *alpha* release of our new REST API, which includes mostly read APIs for individual issues.
We continued to evolve the REST API in 4.3 and 4.4.  We published the REST API documentation for 4.3 and 4.4 releases here:

* [JIRA REST API documentation 4.3|http://docs.atlassian.com/jira/REST/4.3/]
* [JIRA REST API documentation 4.4|http://docs.atlassian.com/jira/REST/4.4/]

In the JIRA 5.0 release we plan to take the JIRA REST API out of beta.  As always, we would love to hear your feedback and comments about this feature. To keep the discussion centralized (both past and present), feel free to comment on this issue with your feedback.

Please note that the JIRA 5.0 version of the REST API has changed significantly from the alpha and beta API from previous releases.  The JIRA 5.0 API goes well beyond the read-only API from previous versions.  The new REST API should include {{create, update, delete, search}} for Issues and manipulation of individual issue fields.

* [JIRA REST API Tutorial|http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/JIRA+REST+API+%28Alpha%29+Tutorial]
* [JIRA REST API documentation 5.0-m3|http://docs.atlassian.com/jira/REST/5.0-m3/]

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-22119].
  {panel}

In the Gliffy JIRA Plugin, we enable customers to create diagrams which are attached to JIRA issues.

Our customers would like to be able to include links in their Gliffy diagrams similar to how we do this in Confluence and Gliffy Online.  

In order to make this work in JIRA, we need to be able to back the diagram image with an image map embedded in a web page.  In order for us to do that, we need a plugin hook into how attachments are rendered.

Here is one possible solution:
* When an attachment is saved, specify a renderer for that attachment
* The renderer could be built in one by Atlassian, or a third party plugin
* When an attachment is shown on the Issue screen, how it is displayed is controlled by the renderer (similar to how macros work in confluence).   We would need to be able to control how the attachment is displayed to the user, and we'd need to be able to control contents of the link that is shown to the user

This would enable us to link Gliffy diagram images to a custom Webwork plugin module/page that would display the image in a web page backed by an image map, hence enabling linking of diagrams to other issues, etc.  

Feature request at Gliffy:
http://support.gliffy.com/entries/246556-jira-plugin-support-links-or-relative-links-in-jira-plugin
fields.summary: JIRA Plugin Module(s) to enable more control over attachments on issues

This is mostly for enabling easier customization of Jira. Please add an id (id="xxx") to all html elements in Jira that are used when users can create issues.

I have (in various projects) customized Jira to prevent certain issue types from being visible to certain users. In 3.x this was easy for example with editing secure\views\createissue-start.jsp and adding a javascript that hides the element from the options list for certain users. In Jira 4.x this still works, but there are 2 new create issue places - both of which do not allow for equally easy customization. However, this could easily be improved if you added id's to the html.
The positions are:
* the Create issue in the upper right-hand corner
* the Create issue links in the project view

This is how I do it in createissue-start.jsp:

document.getElementById("issuetype100004").style.display = 'none'; 

I know of no easier/better way for doing this kind of a customization than a simple javascript that hides the option. Of course, I have added a validator that ensures this also works. The javascript is only for convenience.
fields.summary: Add html id for Jira 4.x create issue elements

Hello,

The Description field is a default field (non-custom), and the 'View Issue' screen only allows you to control the layout of custom fields in the Details section of the 'View Issue' page.
The 'View Issue' page ignores all the non-custom fields display orders on the Screen, and JIRA was designed to show the Description system field as the last one on the Details section.
This means that, even if you set a field to show below the Description, it'll be displayed above it.

If you create two custom fields (e.g. Free Text) and set one to be displayed above and the other to be displayed below the Description field, like this:
1- Custom Field 1
2- Description
3- Custom Field 2

They'll be displayed like this:
1- Custom Field 1
2- Custom Field 2
3- Description

Please let me know if you need further explanation.

Regards,
___________________
Felipe Kraemer
Atlassian Support

I want to be able to create an issue through the email service. The problem is that we currently have 20 projects and 8 issue states which would require me to create 160 email addresses, mail servers, and mail services. This I suppose is a work around to the issue except that the support for this is impossible so I consider a non-starter solution. I sent in a support request dealing with this issue:

https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-62775?page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:all-tabpanel

I looked at both solutions, but the advanced mail handler plug in isn't 4.1 complaint. I will have to create a specialized mail handler but it seems to me that you can already read the issue from the subject since I can use this to comment on existing issues even without any defaults in the handler parameters. I would think it would be possible and very easy since most of the architecture is already set up to overwrite the project and issuetype in the subject of the email. Basically I want to mail something to the email address set up in a service where the subject line would be something like:

project=RM, issuetype=8, issuename=Testing Email Issue Creation for Project RM

and body:

Testing the creating of an issue under project RM.

Which would create a new issue with type 8 under the project RM with an initial comment of "Testing the creating of an issue under project RM."

It seems that there is no way (or none that I'm aware of) how to search for issues that are blocked by unresolved issues, resolved issues or not blocked by other unresolved issues at all (to see which issues I can work on). h3. Problem Definition
JIRA Cloud Supports Google Apps Integration

h3. Suggested Solution
Have a similar feature in JIRA Server products to allow integration with Google Apps Directly. 
 
h3. Workaround

Some suggestions are as below:
# Migrate the Instance to Atlassian Cloud [Migrating from JIRA Server to JIRA Cloud|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CLOUDKB/Migrating+from+JIRA+Server+to+JIRA+Cloud]. 
# Use a Third Party Plugin from the [Atlassian Marketplace|https://marketplace.atlassian.com] such as [OpenID Authentication for JIRA|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.pawelniewiadomski.jira.jira-openid-authentication-plugin/server/overview]
# Use [Atlassian Crowd|https://www.atlassian.com/software/crowd/overview/], and then integrate with Google ID as per the documentation: [Configuring the Google Apps Connector|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CROWD/Configuring+the+Google+Apps+Connector]

h3. Original Request
JIRA Studio- OnDemand-style Google Apps integration for JIRA Standalone would be cool, particularly the Activity Bar and the ability to attach/preview Google Docs.

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}

In JIRA 4, we have advanced capabilities for querying, but they still don't solve this need for us

# the JQL contains (~) operator doesn't work with Reported in Release or the other release fields, because it cannot search the labels for the enumerated values in the pulldowns - the contains operator only works on text fields
# the JQL < and > operators do work, but they return essentially "higher or lower in the select list than the specified value", not "all releases in a particular branch" or "earlier or later releases of this code branch", and its unclear how they handle new entries added at the end or in the middle of the selection list.

The ideal situation would be if the contains operator "did what I mean", facilitating queries like:

"Fix Version" ~ "HF" to find all issues fixed in a hotfix release (HF 1, HF2, etc)
"Reported in Release" ~ "9.0" to find all issues reported against any build of 9.0 (9.0.x, 9.0.32.2,etc)

Is there a workaround we could use or is this currently not supported by JQL?  This feature would allow us to create dynamic filters instead of adding new options to the filter each time options are added to the field we want to search on.
fields.summary: Contains search on select list field using JQL
